texts.shortText:
Typical pufferfish with small, plump body, large head with prominent chin, conspicuous, bulging, eyes and small upwardly-directed mouth, the teeth fused to form a parrot-like ‘beak’. Body soft and swollen with reduced scales and tapering to a narrow tail. Dorsal fin rounded and set far back, above anus.

Species in this group are mostly identified by their distinctive colouration. In this species the upper surface has numerous pale brown spots, which form rosettes surrounding larger white spots. The brown spots along the flanks are arranged into distinct horizontal rows and the underside of body lack spots and fades to pale pink or white.

Global: Western Indian Ocean, from Cape Peninsula eastwards through East Africa and Seychelles to Red Sea and Persian Gulf. Also recently introduced to Mediterranean where it was first recorded in 1987.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.

Carnivorous species feeding on sandy bottoms from intertidal to about 287 m depth. Thought to live for about 4 years. Recently invaded the eastern Mediterranean, probably by moving though the Suez Canal, and is considered a problem species there due to rapidly expanding population. Also appears to have become much more abundant in western a parts of South Africa in recent years.

As with many other members of this family, the flesh contains the potent toxin tetrodotoxin, so fish should be handled with care and not eaten, or allowed to interact with pets.
Feeds mostly on polychaete worms, small bivalves and gastropods, crustaceans and sea urchins.
Matures at about 10 cm length. In the Mediterranean breeds in summer.
Colour pattern fairly unmistakable and one of only a few pufferfish whose distributions extend as far west as Western Cape.
